tip.text:
Sure you've been in your fair share of cafes, but not one quite like this. Owner Aidan, an avid collector and lover of all things natural history, has lovingly (and painstakingly) created a cafe-cum-miniature-natural-history-museum and it's a transportive, singular experience - as close to the cupboard-into-Narnia flex as it's possible to get. From the luxey pastel pink and creme hues; to the foraged branches and moss; to the surreal taxidermy sitting proud, it's an aesthetic rarity - and a reminder that sometimes fetishes can be a good thing.

With the layout of a small gallery, glass cabinets are filled with all manner of fossils, bones, artefacts and specimens. All for sale; all worthy of a momentary browse. And if that tummy starts to rumble, you'll find coffees, cakes and a short breakfast and lunch menu with carefully put together dishes such as Ottolenghi home-baked beans, salsa and beetroot yoghurt on sourdough; manchego and cheddar toastie with truffle oil; or slow roasted garlic and thyme mushrooms on toast. Keep an eye out for a cute garden out back too.

El Garito is so darn discreet youâ€™re half expecting the bartender to give you a round of applause for finding it when you come through the door. It's a diminutive, angular nook that feels like it might have been a broom-closet before someone had the bright idea to turn it into a romantic lil' money maker. And it is romantic and very, very intimate - if you've got secrets you don't want strangers knowing, don't come here and let that tongue get loose.

Cocktails is the rub, and the menu is reassuringly short - five or six very different, strong concoctions to be enjoyed on a high stool, whilst appearing wistful. Dim, dark and cosy, it's got the special 'hidden gem' vibe that would make it ideal for the first or second date flex. We did spy the charcuterie but would probably tip just sticking to the drinks.

There have been rumours going round for a while, but a visit to the excellent Moio proves it: this part of town is fine-dining territory now. The bougie baby of chef JoÃ£o Ferreira Pinto and sommelier Carolina Seibel (who worked together at Portland), it's modern European sharing plates of the highest quality in a cosy, intimate restaurant. Ideal for a dine when time is no object, or when you need to take your taste buds somewhere fancy to make up for not treating them as you should.

With a funky soundtrack, bare bricks and pared-down furniture, itâ€™s a laid-back operation that metaphorically takes your coat off, seats you somewhere comfy and puts you right at ease. And then comes the food! Oh flip. A short menu features intriguing and original dishes: Portuguese morcella with smoked plum; creamy celeriac vichyssoise with frozen grapes; and, our highlight, poached hake with parsnip and vanilla puree, lemon beurre blanc and seasonal greens. The eating equivalent of nestling your head in a plump, cool pillow. This is downright fancy food that's visually, conceptually and tongue-satisfyingly compelling, and makes for a super-special-occasion select.

Cult Danish brewer Mikkel Borg BjergsÃ¸ has a name that rings out in craft beer circles (trust us on that one). Having done it in Denmark for years, he's teamed up with, erm... *checks notes* Rick Astley to bring Shoreditch a Mikkeler bar. Sure, whatever. A stylish, one-room taproom where 15 in-house and 5 guest brews are available by the third, the two-thirds or the pint. These are artfully crafted beers that excite the palette, stimulate the palette, and ask questions of the palette that sometimes the mind canâ€™t answer. Such as: What is that flavouring? And, yes, that artisan goodness comes at a fairly high price.

Inside there's a distinctively minimalist Scandinavian touch, with pastel greens, clean lines and large orbs of light. Itâ€™s quietly cool and sophisticated, making it clear that this really isnâ€™t the one for a session with the boys; instead it's for a solo connoisseur, a post-work tipple, or an evening-starter before heading on elsewhere. When it gets busy - and it does - those hard surfaces donâ€™t do much for the acoustics, so youâ€™ll have to lean in close to make yourself heard.

Farmer J pumps slightly more healthful versions of restaurant classics out of a huge open kitchen - all in modern and fresh looking surrounds. It's pretty sleek looking, if a little city-ish, but softened by the huge windows and abundance of plants. And the menu? Well dinner consists of anything from ponzu salmon and freekeh with herb salad to - at the other end of the scale - mac 'n' cheese and flank steak; basically catering for your cravings whatever they may be.

But we didn't go for dinner, we went in for a brunch that was both bottomless and pretty tasty (if not life changing). We were treated to some of the tastiest bloody marys we've ever had - packed full of punchy harissa - and an avalanche of miso scramble, smashed avo, sausages, grilled greens and banana bread. Don't be fooled by the five-dish deal though, three each is plenty to get you through your two hours of boozing and schmoozing with a grin.

Another hunky restaurant from the Flat Iron crew, who know their meat better than you know your own mother. This London Bridge number has their typical industrial aesthetic, with all the dark wood and low lighting you could ever want - ideal for that under-the-radar date you're trying to swing.

On the menu, expect all those good cuts. You can't go wrong with the classic Â£10 flat iron steak - especially with sides of beef dripping chips, roast aubergine and creamed spinach. Things are getting a little DIY here with customisable bloody mary and ice cream stations - make your inner child well and truly satisfied.

Born in Cambridge, Stem + Glory has made the journey south to bring London's vegans a taste of their fine dining spin on the plant-based life. Like many a vegan joint before it, Stem's look is Pinterest chic: walls are crisp, white, and dripping in foliage with green accents here and there, plus there's an open kitchen.

Menus put their best veg forward with all sorts of eye catching colourful dishes: green curry, blue tacos, and perhaps something pink? They range from healthy and full of crunch (rainbow bowls) to homely and comforting (slow roast tomato gluten-free lasagne or a jackfruit burger); with plenty of sweet goodies (we've our eye on a mango, coconut and ginger cheesecake), quality coffees, smoothies and hearty brunches too.

Attached to the boutiquey Bankside Hotel, this swish restaurant offers a more modern take on the hotel-resto genre. Art and whimsy are everywhere - the decor is stylish but fun with quirky light fittings, curious paintings and geometric shapes meaning plenty to look at and lust over while you wait for your fruity but grown up cocktails. These, depending on which you order, may be garnished with a postcard to be sent wherever you damn please.

The menu offers people pleasers: some fried starters, dips and breads, fresh seafood, pizzette, salads, pasta, lots of fish and a steak option too. Ours was a sweetly succulent scallop with Jerusalem artichoke; some lemony, buttery ricotta gnudi with pine nuts; and a pan fried cod flaking its way into our happy mouths. Sides were fairly heavenly too: from this point forth we will always request carrots in tahini and sesame seeds, and only ever drink Riesling. We finished with a classic and heartwarming soft-centred chocolate pud. These guys aren't exactly reinventing the wheel but they can bang out a right good meal.

If you can't get on board with a laid-back pizza eatery like this, we're not sure we can still be friends. Happy Face is a big, high-ceilinged space in the rapidly evolving King's Cross area where you can come for some damn nice wood-fired pizza, cocktails and a relaxed time of it. Ideal for a group meal when you might sit on the large tables, have some laughs and enjoy the simple pleasure of straightforward, reassuringly tasty pizza.

They're loud, they're busy, the queue is often out the door, but the Barrafina restaurants still teeter on the edge of something beautiful. It's all about counter dining here, sitting up at the open kitchen watching the theatre of it all - which means conversation is peppered with, 'Hey, why didn't we order that it looks amazing?' and, 'Omg, he's been chopping shallots for a lifetime'.

Tapas comes in hot (or cold as the case may be with a cured monkfish number) and is placed in front of you plate by plate. Croquetas are well worth a visit, as are the deliciously runny tortillas and any freshly grilled fish from the specials menu. Just don't fall into the trap of ordering too many fried goods or it can all end up being too rich and oily. We'd make sure to liven things up with a salad or two and leave just enough room for their lionesas (like profiteroles covered in chocolate sauce and vanilla ice cream).

(By the way, this Barrafina is up some stairs on the mezzanine level of Coal Drops Yard. We got a bit lost in there too.)

Set within the shopping metropolis that is Coal Drops Yard, and technically part of Wolf & Badger, this restaurant somehow manages to hold its ground (the fact it has its own entrance probably helps). Hicce pronounced 'ee-chay' means 'of the moment' in Latin. So it's only natural that chef, Pip Lacey, lays on modern and inventive dishes, wouldn't you say?

The food, in all its glory, really is something. From the home-made rye bread with cured meats and home-made pickles to grilled fish, smoked meats and crunchy veg skewers, Pip's cooking sits comfortably between simple and refined. Co-founder Gordy McIntyre meanwhile is on the drinks, choosing biodynamic wines, craft beers and house cocktails to make you feel something. Not bad for a resto in a shopping centre.

The El Pastor dynasty, now in their third location in a massive industrial-looking space in Coal Drops Yard, are flying dangerously close to the mini-chain territory. But after a boozy lunch filling our boots with tacos, tostadas, and frozen margaritas, weâ€™re happy to report that theyâ€™ve managed to maintain the same fruity, smokey authenticity of their original Borough Market outpost.

We kicked things off with a couple of oysters that came loaded with pickled jalapeÃ±os and a citrusy mezcal dressing - a real wake up call - before moving onto more meaty pursuits. The eponymous al pastor was all kinds of smokey and balanced beautifully with caramelised pineapple; whilst the tuna tostada with avocado was limed to perfection, but our favourite was the prawn taco with mojo de ajo, a fantastic mouthful (or two) of textures and zing. Everything is fruity but nothing is too sweet. And that goes for their frozen margzâ€™ as well, which weâ€™d say are compulsory.

This bougie audiophile haven, at the bottom of Royal Festival Hall, is the kind of exquisitely singular experience you'll be patting yourself/Dojo on the back for visiting. It's a damn pleasure: an all-day-eating, late-night-drinking affair where food, drink, music and aesthetic are all given equal billing and suitable for any an occasion. A immersive loosener on your ones; the impressing flex; or an intimate dinner with pals when secrets might be shared as the potent mixture of fantastic cocktails and crystal clear music permeates your soul.

With a decor inspired by 1970s recording studios, itâ€™s a space of deep burgundy booths and orbs of light letting out the absolute minimum glow, thereby heightening every other sense. And those tastebuds are hit with food given high regard. We came in for dinner where experimental Middle Eastern-inspired sharing plates had us drooling over a succulent and rich sweet and sour pork belly with octopus, pomelo, coconut and ground rice; or a novel biber SalÃ§asi cauliflower, kale saag and green mango yoghurt. Our tip would be to stick to this intriguing stuff rather than the conventional meat options.

At the end of the week, a frickinâ€™ fantastic roster of expert selectors spin groove-ridden, rare records as the majority of punters discreetly slip on Auto-Shazam and enjoy themselves an atmospheric night-cap. Whenever you roll in here, the bill is likely to rack up - but we don't think you'll regret it.

The concept at Redemption Bar is simple: they want to challenge the idea that we need alcohol to enjoy every social occasion. So in this laid-back, arty spot there's not a drop of the hard stuff to be seen. Instead, a carefully constructed menu (designed by a nutritional therapist) with plenty of goodness.

That includes vegan, gluten-free and raw food dishes; and for drinks it's smoothies, teas and mocktails. Snaffle a ruby beet ravioli and one of their coco-tinis (coconut water and cranberry shaken over ice with a squeeze of lime) and you'll feel all the better for it. Perfect for health conscious-foodies or those in need of a little redeeming.

Once upon a time (the year was 2011), hidden behind a secret doorway in a residential neighbourhood in Tokyo, a high-quality, high-design coffee stall opened up. Taking inspo from the Japanese tea ceremony this cute little cubic bar featured one barista who would serve up careful coffees focusing on the calm ritual of brewing.

Now dotted about all over the globe Omotesando Koffee stalls are laying on drip filter coffees, cappuccinos, matcha lattes and delish' sweet pastry kashis. If you want a slice of that Insta-friendly action, the Rathbone Square development in Fitzrovia is where you need to be.

SÃ¶derberg is a picture perfect export from Sweden via Edinburgh (they've got three bakeries there already). Their first London spot is a cutesy cafe and bar dishing out beautiful bakes, open sarnies, rye bread and brunch in Scandinavian-inspired surrounds. Head downstairs and you'll find a charming 60s-style lounge, with lots of those coveted Scandi bits: low seating, patterned wallpaper and general cutesy cosiness.

Eating here is a calming and homely affair. Lunch is seen to with 'smÃ¶rgÃ¥s' - slices of sourdough piled with smoked salmon and caviar or brie and fig; brunch is seen to with smoked salmon, avocado, crispy kale and a dill, lemon and crÃ¨me fraÃ®che sauce; and drinks? Flat whites or cocktails depending on your mood.

Whatever you do, don't leave without trying one of their delectable buns which come in all manner of heady flavours.

To say Wild Rice is reinventing Thai food is a stretch, but if you dig the distinct blend of sharp flavours and moreish spices found in Thai cooking then you should consider hitting this place. In a similar mould to Kiln or Smoking Goat, this small restaurant joins the dominant sharing-plate wave with a considered menu of Thai dishes slightly modified with plant-based or seasonal British ingredients.

The intimacy, dark woods and low lights give this place the appropriate relaxed-but-not-too-relaxed kind of vibe, good for a confidential dine but not a big group. The menu ranges from bites to curries via salads and seafood and it's definitely slightly more interesting than the usual Thai, if not exactly packed full of flavour - stuff like tofu nuggets with a creamy satay sauce; crispy mushrooms in a sharp chilli, lime and garlic dressing; and lamb massaman curry. Our pick would be the vermicelli and prawn baked in a tin pot: sweet, comforting and just downright yummy.

If you're after a laid-back bite alone or with pals, this place is a sure-fire winner. Homeslice are known for whipping up some serious pizzas - 20 inches of wood-fired glory. One pizza feeds 2 to 3 people, so at Â£20 a pop these babies really are decent value.

The toppings are primo too - you can get traditional flavours like salami, rocket and parmesan, or more unusual numbers like lamb, savoy cabbage and sumac yoghurt. Choosy dinners can go half-half on the toppings or get some by the slice, then wash the lot down with craft beers, wine or a refreshing Aperol spritz. The simple life, eh?

If youâ€™re a fan of eating little fishes then Simon Whiteside is your man. Born in a small Irish coastal town then working under the likes of Raymond Blanc, he knows when seafood is fresh and he knows what to do with it. Simon's dishes are seasonal and packed with flavour - heâ€™s not afraid to cover a sea bream with salsa verde or fry it into Kerala-spiced tempura batter.

Start with delicate small plates of squid noodles; deep-fried anchovies; or monkfish carpaccio - then move on to heartier mains like spiced pollock with fermented lentils, roast onion, squash and chard. Soak it all up with a hunk of bread and wash it down with a craft beer and you'll soon forget you're in a tiny shipping container in Pop Brixton, a long way from the sea.

Apparently Kutir means 'a small cottage in the middle of nowhere', but after visiting we think they meant to say 'a fancy restaurant in a townhouse just off the King's Road'. People can be silly but chef Rohit Ghai isn't: he knows if you give a restaurant a cute name and fill it with delicious and beautiful things people will come. And we did.

We sat ourselves down on plush seating, surrounded by all sorts of floral wallpaper and decadent Chelsea appeal; we sipped on refined and punchy cocktails (their take on a negroni reaches sweet lofty heights); and we ate some truly delish' aromatic Indian goodies. Dishes here may look elegant but they're packed with spice and heat, and our scrumptious guinea fowl biryani came in a comfortingly generous portion. We finished on a strawb' falooda which brought much in the way of texture but little in the way of flavour; we could happily have swapped it for another round of delicately spiced scallops and aubergine.
